commentBody:
"Hey, I wouldn't use that lemon peel if I were you."
"Rind your own business!"

(This was the zest that I could do.)
Tough but fun! Hope all y‚Äôall have a great Saturday. Thanks, Adrian and Christina!

My comment didn't post yesterday. Normally I'd accept it and move on, but I spent over an hour on it. So I'm gonna try posting it again, but I'll split it into 2 parts. I apologize if it isn't entertaining enough to warrant such a blatant breach of protocol.

[Takes in the trash?] is one of my favorite clues ever. Wow. I'm gonna post a few snippets from my favorite deleted scenes:


"Frankly, my dear ... I think we should give us another shot. You complete me."



"What do you think of your new glasses?"
"They're awesome! I don't see dead people anymore!"




"Boohoo boohoo. 'Come back, Shane, come back, Shane!' There's no crying in the Old West, Joey! So sck it up and tell me what's so goldarn important I had to ride back a goldarn mile with a goldarn bullet in me!"
"I, um, I forgot."
"See, this is why nobody wants to have no kids no more."

Fun puzzle. Great to get it done before I go to sleep. Like so many times, I thought it was getting me and then it came together.

I like to think I‚Äôm good at these and then I see the times of people who beat my good times. It keeps me going. üòä

I felt really good doing this one.  It seemed to hum right along.  I doubt I had to change more than three of fours squares.

So, for me it was a dandy puzzle.  I won't object if people want to consider it rather tame for a Saturday.

I'm thinking a COSLEEPER is a means of being able to sleep safely with an infant?  I've never encountered it.

I thought DANCEMOM was clever.  My mom, in the late 50s when I was still single digit age, wanted me to learn to tap dance.  My WWII veteran father, a no nonsense kind of guy, quietly put the kibosh on that, much to my relief. 

Although, now, I kind of wish I'd learned to dance at some point in my life.  I think I would have had a lot more fun.  I certainly would have had more dates.

I'm long past thinking I'll ever remember the names of the Three Musketeers.  I really didn't get into that story as a kid.  Something about those dainty little bendy swords and precious little thin mustaches.  I preferred the hirsute Vikings and their rigid swords.(Calling Dr. Freud...)

Good solid Saturday, fun clues and interesting answers.  I liked DANCEMOM, LEGOSETS (shout out to my LEGO obsessed grandson), LASERMAZE, and STORYARCS.  RENTACAR tripped me up for a bit because I wanted it to be rental.  I smiled when I saw PENN (my law school alma mater) clued as Brown alternative (gotta love those disguised capitals).

And how could I not love a puzzle with a clue pairing my two favorite male soul singers (apologies to Smokey Robinson).  Cupid and Wonderful World sung in Sam Cooke‚Äôs ultra smooth voice are as good as soul/pop music gets, and A Change Is Gonna Come gives me chills every time I hear it.  As for Marvin Gaye, there are many versions of I Heard It Through The Grapevine, but none better than his.  Just as good were his efforts to meld soul music with social awareness like What‚Äôs Going On and Mercy Mercy Me (the ecology).  But most of all nothing could put you in the mood more than his Let‚Äôs Get It On.  Sadly, both of them died violent deaths way too early.

Now that's a puzzle. Many, many groan inducing clues. Not sure if this was intentional, but NEED/S and SEAS would have been valid/plausible responses to two different clues. I put them both in the wrong spot and ruled out them as an answer to the right spot because I had already used them elsewhere. Took a long time to correct those. 25 minutes in the end, but it felt a lot longer. 10 week streak now, 70 days, twice as long as my previous best
A shame you threw shade on Hayley Mills the original "twins" on the Parent Trap.  Lindsay Lohan had lots of screamingly funny roles besides this remake.

Somehow out of the deep recesses of my memory BACTRIAN appeared.  Until then I was at an impasse on the west side.   Then I loved EMERYBOARD.  Kept racking my brain for computer terms until the crosses slammed my palm to my forehead.

Very nice, thanks!
It's how I always remember it. BACTRIAN camels have two humps like the letter B. Dromedary camels have one hump like the letter D.

That was really fun to solve.

Thanks Adrian and Christina.

For a while, instead of 
STORYARCS I had
SnOwpAckS

My last letter change to get the happy music was
STORYARkS to
STORYARCS

Too much Indiana Jones, I suppose.....
A serious question. Do LASER MAZEs exist outside filmdom?
It's a Saturday crossword and yet we have LEMONRIND for "Zest source." Why so literal? Please toughen up the late-in-the-week puzzles. Thanks

I so badly wanted ONEline as ‚ÄúSimplest phone plan‚Äù to cross with LiNkedIn as ‚ÄúEnterprise enterprise‚Äù as I didn‚Äôt have much else in the SE. 

Overall a tough but fair Saturday!
At one point, for 41A, I had B_C_RI__, and in a myopic (and likely presbyopic) moment thought, "Surely it can't be 'bi-curious!'"  Mercifully not.
Completion time was 40% less than average , but I did have my solving partner help me.  Fun themeless.

I could only remember single humper - dromedary.
Thank you for the reminder - I hope to memorize two-humper but alas, I am at the stage of life where I am forgetting more than I could acquire or reacquire information.

I had to look up SHADE (never heard of this usage), FEY (I know of her, but I'm not familiar with "Mean Girls" and who was involved), ACCRA (I know the city but not what it translates to, and at the time I looked it up I had almost nothing there so I desperately needed crosses), BEES, POI (never heard of it), LEO (I never bothered to learn about zodiac signs, associating them with superstition), ORTON (well, duh; the familiar Randy Savage wouldn't fit), and EVERY.

With those hurdles out of the way I was able to complete the puzzle. 

BACTRIAN was a gimme, strangely. I learned it when I played hangman with my maternal grandmother as a kid. She used it to hang me ü§∑üèΩ. She was not a nice person. But at least I learned the word. Back then I remembered everything I heard and saw. The Polish spelling is almost the same, we just use a K where you do a C.

I also guessed LOHAN even though I've never seen the film (or any other featuring her). I must have heard of it in the past.

What's a community court? Either we don't have that over here or we call it something completely different.

I took Lucyfer the puppy on his first long-ish walk yesterday, to get raspberries at the farmers market. On our way back we met a lady walking a young standard poodle, a lovely girl with a perfect white coat. She was so tall! Lucek will probably be even larger. So cool! Today we will go for his first walk in the forest.

I just had a weird number coincidence happen that caught my attention. Today is my 1542 day streak of solving these puzzles AND I solved this one 15:42 faster than my average ü§Ø I just shared the screenshot with my family I was so excited ü§£ I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôre rolling their eyes at me üôÑ Anyhow, I enjoyed this one. I retired my Irish DANCE MOM status this past year. I will kind of miss creating those crazy wig updos for my daughter, but I‚Äôm appreciating getting my weekends back. 
Thank you, Adrian and Christina!
Today I learned that "horse race" and "bowler hat" have the same number of letters.

I guess I was vibing with the constructors. This feel pretty easily. Much easier than last Saturday. 

I think I woulda crushed this if I didn‚Äôt get hung up on ‚Äúsimplest phone plan‚Äù as ONEline instead of ONERATE. 

Bees from tears doesn‚Äôt make sense to me. But I guess sadness of tears begets angry bees?

Fun Saturday which restored my confidence (until next Saturday). Thanks.

this saturday bactrian fought me, spat and grunted at me and im pretty sure even sat on me at one point.
finally got to the oasis after a grueling hour.
Usually on a Saturday, my guesses are way off. Today, it just clicked for some reason. Less than 40% of my average Saturday time :) I should get up to organise the kids' breakfasts now.....

When I saw the names of Adrian and Christina, I knew that this crossword would be a treat, and it really was (not lying to anyone!). Smart clues and a flawless fill. One awkward entry here and there is fine, and the crosses were generous enough for them. Great experience!
My first thought for Ra's tears was SEAS, which, oddly turned up elsewhere in the grid. But the really odd thing is that's not the first time that's happened -- this week.
Thanks Adrian and Christina, including for the quad stacks. Most enjoyable.

Quite tough today, several words I didn't know, and the names, as usual. The pressing/ironing/evening clues are popular at the moment!

By the way, in the UK the usage is 'actor' for both males and females, is that not the case in the US?

But, I got there in the end.

Right off the bat, when 1D and 3D echoed yesterday's puzzle, I wondered briefly if we were being punked.  

I was unfamiliar with LASER MAZE and NAZCA, but after a quick mental alphabet check brought up nothing else, I went with the Z.

A fun puzzle today with a nicely calibrated challenge. My only issue is cluing "bonus entry" as a "kind of contest." An "entry" is not a type of contest any more than an "at bat" or "overtime period" is a type of sport, even if that is the realm in which they occur.
Surely 25A should be [Brick buildings] not [Components for brick buildings]?

The magic of eight hours of sleep! I hit a wall about two-thirds of the way through last night, and then steadily knocked out the remainder while enjoying my first mug of tea on the screen porch on this delightful 64 degree morning.

What a diverse collection of answers in the box today. 

‚Ä¢	People types -- POET, SLOB, DANCE MOM, LONERS.  
‚Ä¢	Places to go ‚Äì DENS, REC CENTERs, SEAS.
‚Ä¢	Animals ‚Äì BEES, FLEAs, BACTRIAN camels, LEOs with dens, HORSEs racing.
‚Ä¢	Tastes ‚Äì POI, LEMON RIND, ATTA.
‚Ä¢	Utterances ‚Äì AS IF, AHOY MATEY, LIE TO ME, I CARE.
‚Ä¢	Things from the past ‚Äì RUNESTONE, NAZCA lines, ARGOS.

Each of these triggered images and memories, which brought brain pings ‚Äì pinpoints of light where the mind was sleeping, -- and what started out as riddle cracking became an outing as well.

And what‚Äôs an outing without a funny moment?  Mine was when I convinced myself that there was such a thing as a Mondrian camel. 

Sure, this was a solve, Christina and Adrian.  But it was a happening, a rich experience as well.  Thank you both!

A Saturday puzzle I actually enjoyed! I didn‚Äôt solve it without lookups and Auto Check but I was amused by several clues. My fave was 15D [Digital file?]. And no boring filler! Kudos to Adrian and Christina!
Lovely puzzle that could have been switched with the Friday one
Maybe someone has already pointed out that "BONUSENTRY" is an potential *aspect* to a game and not a kind of game.

Thought I had solved it, but one square was amiss. Couldn't find my error after several checks. I had HASNO for "lacks," and ATOA for flour. Finally I realized HASNO could also be HASNT and flour could be ATTA. That did it.

Whew. And Wow! Typical tough Saturday for me, and had to look up some things early on but then just had a ton of 'aha' moments as I worked things out from the crosses. And... seven debut answers in this one, but only two of them were completely unfamiliar terms to me. That's pretty amazing. A couple of puzzle finds today. First one is a Tuesday from February 21, 2006 by Lisa Wiseman. Here are the three theme clues and answers: "Always" EIGHTDAYSAWEEK "Occasionally" ONCEINABLUEMOON "Time that won't come in all eternity" TWELFTHOFNEVER Thought that was pretty clever. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/21/2006&g=35&d=A I'll put my other puzzle find in a reply. ....
I wanted [Enterprise enterprise] to be something like BOLDLY GO (where no man has gone before). üññ

I was surprised that I solved the NW corner quite quickly and thought this would be a quick solve for a Saturday. But I had to look up some answers, as I don't follow WWE and I had no idea of the flour. The SE corner took a long time, and I finally solved the brick building clue last; that answer made me smile. I finished slightly faster than my average. Fun puzzle.
The puzzle didn‚Äôt click for me today, but the message board made me smile.  Thanks all!

Okay, I'm completely baffled.  I've looked up the definition in case I misunderstood the word, but it confirmed my understanding.  Would someone mind taking a moment and explaining to me how "SATED" is the answer to "kept hidden, as information."  
According to the dictionary, there are two meanings:
"1: to cloy with overabundance : glut
2: to appease by indulging to the full"
Nothing about being hidden.  I've never heard of information being "sated" in any event.  What am I not understanding?

As feared, 10 minutes over average to continue my trend for the week. I need a nap after this one. SO many false starts, from thinking natural history had to start with BIO to LASEREYES to SEMAPHORE for ship-to-ship communication to  LEMONPEEL instead of RIND to desperately trying to fit something Star Trekky into Enterprise enterprise. 

So much bactrian-tracking. But, a solid relief when the gold star popped! Great workout!

Loved this puzzle just the right amount of difficulty. And I will give a thumbs up to anything that references the Parent Trap remake‚Äîused to watch it in the car every single road trip with my kids, it never got old. The single best family film ever made in my opinion. Amazing sound track and the resplendent Natasha Richardson who left us way too soon.

Speaking of DANCE MOMs, my fellow Kentuckian Steve Zahn has just released a movie, "She Dances", in which he has to become a DANCE DAD to chaperone his dancer-daughter, who co-stars in the movie. https://tribecafilm.com/films/she-dances-2025 I'm curious to see if the movie will get a wide release.

"I particularly noticed and appreciated the ancient history trivia, a nice break from trendy factoids"

I liked those a lot too! Not an ELM or OREO in sight either, I think.

Holy cow.  
PhysicsDaughter and I ended up with some sharing...between the type (ye olde r+n and m confusion) and her eyes that currently can't work together (next cataract surg is Monday, h'ray!) it's not surprising that she needed help even reading the clues.  
She gave me the first two letters of 11D and I suggested that she think of her brother for 25A.  
"The Parent Trap" has been remade at least twice too often...IMHO.  
This really GRATES nope CHAFES.  
And I was so, so proud to think of AQABA for 9A....
Could have happily lived out my life w/out being reminded of Erich SEGAL and his sappy, soppy novella...but oh well.

See you guys tomorrow.

42:52, 17:58 faster than average. Went pretty much clockwise starting top left. The Ship-to-ship was my favorite clue. The Athens clue led me down a rabbit hole on which ancient Green cities still exist. Enjoyed the fill.
55A is NOT a protest anthem. There should be better fact checking for something like this.
I thought this was a really good puzzle. Challenging in a fun way.
This puzzle was pure delight. Thank you!

Whoa! Most incredible puzzle I've ever come across. A Sunday from December 31, 1972 (that date is important) by the great Frances Hansen with the title: "Time remembered." Five 23 letter grid-spanning theme answers, all tied to each other. Some examples: Verse, with 45, 79, 112 and 128 Across : 29a -TELLMETELLMEISITTRUENOT "More of verse" HINGSLEFTOFSEVENTYTWOTI "More of verse" MESATHIEFWEOUGHTTOBANWO "More" ULDITSPOILSOMEAWESOMEPL "End of verse" ANIFIWROTEMYCONGRESSMAN Wow. Just wow. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/31/1972&g=112&d=A ....

Found this one a bit harder than yesterday's, but got it solved without assistance in about 35 minutes. ROUNDROBIN instead of BONUSENTRY (which is new to me) slowed me down. Also, didn't know that a COSLEEPER is a type of furniture, and not just a bed partner.

Very solid Saturday puzzle that was fun to solve.
I wish that 55A had been clued as ‚ÄúBlack national anthem‚Äù rather than the generic ‚Äúprotest anthem‚Äù.  America simply could not exist without Black people.

AHOY MATEYs! Just wondering how many here know what an Aldis lamp is? If you've ever watched "Sink the Bismarck" or other such movies, those are the round lights with the shutters whereby ships communicate with Morse code. But it fit the squares, as did semaphore. Laughed when I finally got 17A.

Curious mix of gems and clunkers today, most of which have been cited already. Is LEO a period of time associated with the Zodiac sign? I don't read the horoscopes, so I don't know any of that "moon is in the seventh house" jargon.

Apparently, it's "Fat Bear Week," as our ursine friends pack on the last few kilos of fat to prep for hibernation, so DENS was timely.

The university was just in one of the puzzles so I confidently entered EMoRYBOARD; that and my FaY caused the logjam in the NE in an otherwise smooth and fun solve.  (Yes, eyebrow raised at 55A).  Nicely done.

Very fun themeless solve this morning, Adrian and Christina - I hope we see more collaborations from the two of you! 

Alas, I missed matching my personal Saturday Best by 40 seconds due to an untimely, non-emergency distraction in my household! Needless to say, it HIT A NERVE!üò©üòÇ

Well... I was going to complain that "cosleeper" isn't an item and it should have been "cosleeping" but later found I was completely wrong, that in-bed cosleeping is a big no-no, and that "cosleeper bassinets" are a thing.

Can I still complain that "laser mazes" aren't really a design part of any security system (except, as noted in Wordplay, heist movies and the Traitors TV show)?

How about that the rind isn't a proper zest source because it includes the pith?

Ah, anyway, nits aside, a fun ride, and probably a tad easy for a Saturday.  About even with Friday's (which wasn't itself hard).

A challenging Saturday offering that puzzled me for a good while.
Many things I did not know: RUNESTONE, BONUS ENTRY, LASER MAZE, ICE MELT, and that "punk" means PSYCH OUT. And I was surprised to learn that Aldous Huxley had written about LSD as early as 1954, more than a decade before it registered on the public's awareness when Leary and Alpert were at Harvard.
Did three-fourths of the puzzle in record time and then got stuck on a handful of entries. The NAZCA-LASERMAZE cross was punishing!

I found this one appropriately challenging. I love entries like COSLEEPER and LASER MAZE. I didn't know either one by name, but once I got close to completing them I knew they were correct.

The all-too-infrequent commentator of late, Puzzlemucker, once said that what Mike(from Munster) does is a lot harder than it looks. I whole-heartedly agree.

Most of us can come up with occasional puns, but to pick a relevant topic every single day and then, well, we all know the amazing and entertaining work he does and what a great guy he is and how lucky we are to have him here.

Why on Earth would somebody go after him? 

I don't like anyone attacking anyone here, but it would at least make sense if you were to question someone inconsistent and frequently incomprehensible, unfunny, rude, smug or annoying. (I'm too polite to name names, and I don't want to hurt my feelings.)(Everyone is welcome to tell me I'm none of those things, i.e., LIE TO ME.)

Please keep doing what you do, Mike!

‚ÄúWith one breath, with one flow, you will know‚Ä¶‚Äù
I had to give a hearty laugh at seeing BACTRIAN come together.  There is absolutely no way I would have known this except for the fact that I have just started reading the 4th book in the Dungeon Crawler Carl series (great read for any D&D/HitchHiker fans) where the local population are the two different types of camels.  Reading is indeed, fundamental.  
Had fun with this one - a nice Saturday.
1 down is not slang it is AAVE

Had to fight through every inch of this one except for the SW. Knowing the camel helped with that area. But it was interesting how, when I had SH_ _B and tried to imagine it with a U in that second blank, I couldn't come up with anything. On the next round when I finally typed in a U, I saw it immediately. Thought I was good at visualizing, but this was one of those perceptual quirks that NYT puzzles tend to trigger that I find just totally fascinating. 

This was appropriate Saturday level for me.

I had fun with this puzzle. Two minutes below my average.  I knew nazca--sort of. I spelled it with S and couldn't figure out what was wrong. Couldn't figure out what a laser mase was. Then I put in the Z and all was well. Thanks for a fun puzzle

Sheesh. I started out breezing through this, thinking I was really on the right wavelength. Maybe I'll even get a PB! Nope. Not even close! The bottom half had me thoroughly stumped! I refused to let go of STARTREK for much too long. 
Excellent clues all around. Thanks for the challenge and for teaching me some new words! (I'm looking at you, BACTRIAN and NAZCA).

Great Saturday puzzle, to me it seemed like a warm welcome in the NW corner to get the solving going that got more difficult as it went along, following a ‚ÄúU‚Äù shaped path and finishing up in the NE corner.   Not sure if that was the intent, but it had a nice effect for me!
It‚Äôs completed and I have quadruple checked every answer but it keeps saying something is wrong?   What am I missing that‚Äôs not obvious?
Fun Saturday--felt easier to me than yesterday's, and that's just fine. Also: "Digital file" ftw!
I do nothing but indulge myself. Hands up from me...

One of my most satisfying solves I can remember, numerous attempts over about 12 hours, I finally removed the paper after emery and it all fell magically into place. The best type of Saturday puzzle in my book, really challenging with nothing at all unfair

Fun Saturday for me and very unlike my usual Saturday struggle. I almost hated to see it end. Got off to a good start & at about 3/4 through went to my granddaughter's softball game(they won handily). Got home and finished with our new puppy's help and no puppy nips.
In the minority here but did not like this puzzle at all. COSLEEPER and LASERMAZE seem like lazy entries to me.
Fun solve but took me forever!

Phew, that was a tough one! I had to take a break and come back to it a couple hours later but finally managed to crack it. I had "semaphore" for 17A for quite some time before finally getting AHOY MATEY. NE corner was the real stumbling block though. Clearly I need to bone up on African capitals!

Mikes puns, Lewis daily dissections and acknowledgments, these are joy bringers.  I'm remembering several years back one thoughtful soul often included a musical link( I loved those), So it's all sorts of different souls making joy with words, How fortunate are we!
So the answer to 12D CLASSIC ROCK, is that a reference to the Led Zepplin album with the rune stones as a title, the one with Stairway to Heaven?

I like Mike's puns, and could someone please explain 53D.  I got it from the crosses, but...?

Thank you.
Yesterday I shed blood, sweat and tears to get to the gold star. Today I confidently strode through the clues, filling in answers with aplomb. Oh, the agony and the ecstasy of crosswords!

Just wanted to say that 28-D is a top tier clue and was literally the last answer that I filled out. It truly gave me that satisfactory frisson when I figured it out!

And I also like Mike‚Äôs puns I guess
Finally finished a Saturday with no help! My heart was pounding when I put in the last letter (STORYARCS) and couldn‚Äôt believe there were no crumbs!
Just wondering if anyone knows why the ‚ÄúFree from our archives‚Äù mini-puzzle is never accessible? When you click on it it says you need a subscription, but it‚Äôs under the free listings.

I was tickled and slightly shocked today when I achieved a Saturday Gold Star in 29 minutes.  I don't rush, look things up, or try for a streak.  I'm just enjoying the AHA moments!  (with all you folks!)

DIORAMAS  French fashion designer meets Latin 101? 

I will have to go read about Ra and the bees.  I had seas in there.
Laser Maze brought this to mind for me: https://youtu.be/W8B-4-xdqaA?si=aXP0Y38Zq8cYfBDE For the impatient, go to the 2:00 mark. One of the best undead movies of the 2000s.
Sadly, I've never heard of a 'COSLEEPER' and when running the alphabet, I skipped 'C'.  Oh well.  Otherwise a nice puzzle.
This was a very tough one for me, 16 minutes over my average.  Still can't figure out how an emery board is a digital file, or how the period that begins on July 23 is Leo.

This puzzle made me groan in the best way.  EMORYBOARD nearly took me out--I had the EM and thought it was EMAIL but that would have be too straight forward. I literally had to get every thing but the "Y" to make the connection and once I did I had to take a moment and just scream into my hands because of how good of a clue it was and how long it took me to figure it out. Those are the best solves--the ones that take ages but when they fall into place you realize it could be no other way.

Wow, that one took me a while. In the end I was nearly defeated over the [Paratha flour] crossing with [lacks], as HAS No seems a perfectly acceptable substitute for HASNT. Took me one lookup for that one in the end.

@Mike may I politely ask why you do this with almost every puzzle? I would ask the question my mother would: what would happen to this message board if everybody indulged themselves this way? Has no one ever asked?
@Jake G. What‚Äôs the point of the message board?

@Jake G

Let‚Äôs take a poll. Hands up if you like Mike‚Äôs puns. üôå
Yeah if everyone on these comments made silly puns it would get old, and then certainly Mike would stop. Not sure everyone else‚Äôs would be as witty, but none the less. Why spoil the fun and make someone feel bad who is trying to entertain?
Lastly, most days just about EVERYONE has many of the same complaints and gripes, but despite the fact that they  are already posted a zillion times they have to keep reposting. So, maybe you should ask your mom to get on them too.

@Mike

(I'll try this again.  The emus must have loved it so much they SATON it.)

Orange you glad I'm not doing the tired old "orange" pun?

I really don't see the apeel.

Then I went on to say that I really enjoy sparring with Mike, even though he puts me on the mat every time.  It's like getting the chance to strike out to Sandy Koufax.
@Mike I love your puns.  A high point of my day.
@Jake G I don't always need to open the column when working on the puzzle, but I do come to read the comments to see what pun Mike has come up with!
Same here! It‚Äôs become my nightly ritual to finish solving and then come straight to this comments section to read Mike‚Äôs pun du jour!

@Mike

Mike from Munster is the Man in my book and is one of the select group of people I seek out here each day. We‚Äôd be the lesser for his absence.

@Jake G

What would happen if everyone indulged themselves this way?

First off you seem to  imply that he is doing something wrong which is just wrong.

To answer your Mom's question: we'd end up with a few more clever puns ( like we often do now) and another few stretchy ones (like we often do now) and probably a bunch of poor quality ones.  Luckily people who comment here have the good taste not submit the poor quality ones.

I think you are the first and hopefully the only one to ask.

@Jake G
I think Mike does it because people like it.  He gets a lot of upvotes.  I don't think it's more complicated than that.

@SP

üñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏èüñêÔ∏è!!!

@Mike
Another pithy pun!  

The comments wouldn't be the same without you, Mike, and we worry when you're not here.  

Jake, everyone who comments on the puzzles is "indulging" themself.  It's what the comments are for, to share opinions, gripes, stories, and time after time, Mike's brilliant puns are at the top of the list because people love them.

@Jake G personally I dislike puns quite a lot. They rub my brain the wrong way... I actually scroll quickly past Mike's daily post just to try and not read it üôà (true story Lol). 

But no way you're going to get anywhere this crew, they love the puns. So let's let them enjoy their pun. It's all pun and games to them. (Ok that was actually painful for me Lol please don't ever make me do that again)

@SP üôåüèºü´∂üèºüôãüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
I literally look for Mike the Punster from Munster  as well as Lewis Rothstein‚Äôs posts every day. My day isn‚Äôt complete without them!!

@Jake G you may think his jokes are rotten because he‚Äôs a pun gent. Personally I love his gags, even if they occasionally grate! 
So‚Ä¶
Don‚Äôt have a thin skin!
Don‚Äôt be sour!

@The X-Phile

I‚Äôve actually been pondering this lately. Not that we should change it but ask yourself: there isn‚Äôt a best female director category, or best female screenwriting category, or anything like that. So why is that? Seems like when the Oscars were established there had to have been one of three reasons for dual acting awards: 1) women have a different sort of acting style and should be judged under different criteria; 2) they recognized an underling bias and felt like women would not be judged fairly alongside men, or recognized that women did not get by the same quality of roles or 3) they had a real bias and thought that women could not act as well as men and therefore should be judged separately. So ask yourself is that still the same today? If not why not have a best acting category of ten men and women and give to two? Again I‚Äôm not advocating this, I love the glitz and glamor of the Oscars and it seems right; but it‚Äôs an interesting thought experiment.

@JS
Oddly enough, I was just this afternoon discussing how Yiddish and Hebrew are related. Yiddish is written in Hebrew script and, although its basic framework is German, it has borrowed omnivorously from everywhere. But the Hebrew letters are /pronounced/ differently in Yiddish, similar to the Cantonese/Mandarin split as I understand it. So the Yiddish word for "truth" could be either aleph-mem-tet, which is the Hebrew form but is unpronounceable in standard Yiddish orthography, or ayin-mem-ayin-samech, perfectly sensible to a Yiddish reader but without visible connection to the Hebrew word.
